etymology.interpretation: Many analyses treat it as an ideogrammic compound: 口 ‘mouth’ referring to orders or speech, with an upper component suggesting a person/hand overseeing, yielding the sense of taking charge. Others simply view it as depicting an official in charge; the lack of consensus leaves its precise formation uncertain.

examples.english: He is in charge of this matter.

examples.chinese: 他久司礼仪(他久司禮儀)。
examples.english: He has long administered the rites.
